reviewText: Because this season of "The Simpsons" is a keeper!Moving past the flimsy packaging, I must say, this season definitely lives up to the seasons past. I consider myself a pretty big fan of "The Simpsons," but I haven't seen every episode (who has, honestly?). When I bought the previous five seasons, I was satisfied, but kind of bored after a few viewings, as I knew 99% of the episodes by heart already. It was more of a nostalgic trip than anything for me. But it seems like "Season 6" episodes are a bit less common than the ones before it. I had never seen a good chunk of these episodes, not even watching the show in syndication. Picking up this DVD set for me was like finding a treasure. There are loads of goodies to be found in this season. For starters, look at the guest list -- Meryl Streep, Winona Ryder, James Earl Jones, Susan Sarandon, Patrick Stewart, and the cast of "Cheers!" The episodes are a little more well-crafted than before, and even get with the current events (even if it dates the show), with "Bart Vs. Australia" being the prime example. The cliff-hanger ending with "Who Shot Mr. Burns" was a brilliant way to segue into the next season, as Mr. Burns literally earns an assassination. Other highlights of this season include "Lisa's Wedding" where a fortune-teller gives Lisa a glimpse into her future, "Homie The Clown," where Homer goes to clown college, "Bart's Comet," where the town hides in Ned Flanders bomb shelter, only to cast out Flanders himself, "Homer Badman," where Homer is mistaken for having sexually harassed a babysitter, and "Bart's Girlfriend," which has Bart dating the devilish daughter of Reverend Lovejoy.There are a whopping 25 episodes in total to choose from, and as always, there is audio commentary for each episode, with numerous special guests (David X. Cohen of "Futurama" fame even pops up). The rest of the special features fall into form, with deleted scenes, animatics and what-not. Basically, if you've pruchased the first five seasons, there's no reason to stop now. The sixth season of "The Simpsons" is just as funny as before. If the "Homer Head" that the set is packaged in bothers you, there's a card included that tells you how you can get an alternate box. You have to pay shipping and handling, and it's basically just a slipcase that goes over Homer's Head, but you can't please everyone. Personally, I can get over the fact that it doesn't fit on my shelf properly. It's what's inside the counts. And yes, I do see the irony in that, as Homer's head is virtually empty.

reviewText: First off, if you don't like the new Homer head packaging, there is a slip enclosed with this set which contains a phone number you can call to get a different box which matches the ones used for the previous seasons.  It's free, except for a small shipping and handling fee.Speaking of the new packaging, it's okay, but not great.  The discs are easier to get to because the box doesn't fold out -- you access each disc on it's own "page" of the inner packaging.  But the plastic used for the outer case (Homer's head) is flimsy, and the glue used to hold the disc sleeves in place isn't firm -- on my set, the disc sleeves shifted downward a good inch, making it impossible to place the disc holder back inside the head.  I had to carefully peel the sleeves off the cardboard backing and then reattach them.  Needless to say, I'll be sending away for the old-style packaging.As for the season itself, it's fantastic.  A lot of shows start to falter by their sixth season (provided they last that long), but this is a strong season throughout, with some classic episodes.  It includes, among others, "Lemon Of Troy" (where the kids of Shelbyville steal Springfield's lemon tree), "Bart's Comet" (where Bart discovers a comet -- go figure), "The PTA Disbands" (where...you get the point), and the season cliffhanger, "Who Shot Mr. Burns? (Part One)".  In fact, the packaging and menus all follow a "Who Shot Mr. Burns?" theme.  It's nicely done, though I think they're paying too much attention to that particular episode when there are several classics in this set.  "Lemon Of Troy" is one of my all-time favorites, not only for its humor, but for the way it accurately captures life as a 10-year-old (I know, I know, that sounds corny, but if you haven't seen the episode, check it out and you'll know what I mean).Each episode has a commentary track and there are some nifty extras as well.  The menu system is identical to the previous set, allowing you to easily view an episode (or all of the episodes on a disc) without having to wade through a series of menus (as was the case on the first 3 Simpsons season sets).Highly recommended!

reviewText: Season 6 is probably my favorite season yet, and in a special feature, series creator Matt Groening voices his agreement.  Some of the most memorable episodes from the entire series are in this season, including part one of the only 2 part episode in Simpsons history (and my two favorite episodes), Who Shot Mr. Burns?.As usual, the episodes are full of hilarious jokes, great homages and references, and wonderful voice work from the main cast as well as famous guest stars (this year, we get Winona Ryder, Mandy Patankin, Mel Brooks, Kelsey Grammer, Jon Lovitz, Phil Hartman, and James Earl Jones, among others).  In some of the greatest episodes ever (to paraphrase the Comic Book Guy), Springfield hosts a film festival and Jay Sherman of the TV show The Critic makes a guest appearance, Homer joins the Stonecutters, led by Patrick Stewart, Bart is involved in a Rear Window-esque situation, Homer is nearly arrested for sexual harrassment, we learn that Marge has a fear of flying, Bart becomes a wanted criminal in Australia, Bart and some friends go to war with the neighboring town of Shelbyville when the beloved lemon tree is stolen, and Mr. Burns angers everyone in town which leads to him getting shot by an unknown assailant.I must make special mention of Who Shot Mr. Burns?.  As I said, those two episodes have long been my favorite from the entire series, but I never appreciated how brilliantly they were written until I watched the commentary for the episode.  They writers knew exactly who it was that shot him, and there were plenty of (subtle) clues that could help viewers come to the right conclusion.  Also, there were plenty of (equally subtle) ways to rule out most suspects.  In fact, these two episodes were some of the best dramatic television in a long time, yet they were comedies.I'll end this review by saying, once again, that this is a great year of The Simpsons, and everyone should watch it.  It'll make you laugh and think.

reviewText: Though it might be unusual to do so, I'll list the negative first: Bad packaging. Inconvenient. Homer's head is interesting, but it does not work well on my shelf.There. That's out of the way. Now, the good stuff.Finally, on DVD, is the sixth season of the longest running cartoon is history. Never mind that most other series never last longer than five years, or that the Simpsons are still on the air over 10 years later. The first five seasons are funny. Season six is hilarious.I could go through the episode list, but you can read adequate iterations of that here already. Besides, these are rerun frequently through Fox syndication. Any Simpsons fan knows these shows by heart.Sideshow Bob is highlighted in one, Maggie in another, and Mr. Burns has plenty to deal with when he gets shot. Itchy and Scratchy's theme park goes awry, Patty and Selma hook up Homer with a loan, and even Santa's Little Helper gets into action. It is no longer a show that focuses on Homer and Bart. Instead, the writers stretch into new areas and ideas that grant the Simpsons great staying power.Two songs are worth noting, "Jazzman" and "The Stonecutter's Song."When Bleeding Gums, Lisa's jazz mentor, passes away, they sing "Jazzman" beautifully. It is a sad episode that is surprisingly inspring.In the episode when Homer joins a secret society, "The Stonecutter's Song," is fantastically funny as most of Springfield's male adults grab their beers and sing in chorus:"Stonecutters: Who controls the British crown?Who keeps the metric system down?We do! We do!"These are the episodes when the Simpsons show development as characters. Six years into the series, they have history, complicated storylines and maturity. They are nuanced, with personalities more complex that what might be expected in a cartoon. It is no longer just a rebellious, edgy show, but becoming quickly part of Americana that now crosses two generations.Extras? The usual. The most important extra is what you'll regularly enjoy, the completeness of these complete episodes. No commercials, and entire episodes. They are as the show was originally shown, not squeezed down for the rerun market.I fully recommend "The Simpsons - The Complete Sixth Season." Try not to watch it all in one weekend, though. You don't want to have to see Dr. Hibbert or Dr. Nick Riviera for a stiff neck.Anthony Trendleditor, HungarianBookstore.com

reviewText: The change in packaging was perhaps a clever symbol of how the direction of the show had shifted. The first five seasons of The Simpsons had worked hard in establishing a dysfunctional family brilliantly and many of society's facets in detail. However, in season six the direction has gone more wacky, which was pre-warned in earlier seasons with episodes like the Monorail. The old writers were gone, Al Jean and Mike Reiss had gone to The Critic, Conan's had his talk show and Dave Mirkin was running free to parody every story telling convention you can think of. What happened in season six is that attention to character and story structure was shifted towards gags and you had some genuine clunkers unlike the previous seasons where the only thing holding back some of the episodes was the pacing. This is of course only the beginning of their decline, it wouldn't be really noticable until Mike Scully took over and paid even less attention to the characters, so there's still a lot of brilliant classic episodes.Some of the greatest episodes include;Itchy & Scratchy LandTreehouse Of Horror VHomer BadmanHomer The GreatAnd Maggie Makes ThreeBart's CometLisa's WeddingWho Shot Mr. Burns? (Part One)However, there's no denying the clunkers;Another Simpsons Clip Show <- It's a clip show, sure. However, the clip show in season four was absolutely fantastic what they did with it. What happened here?Bart Vs. Australia <- This was a subtle satire on the caning incident in Korea but the gags were very cheap here.Homer Vs. Patty & Selma <- This one goes no where and the appearance of Susan Sarandon is absolutely gratuitous.A Star Is Burns <- Funny, but shameless.'Round Springfeild <- This is the one where Bleeding Gums dies and it lacked all the sincerity that made Moaning Lisa great.There a bit of leeway here because some of the mediocre episodes in this season are still better than most, if not all, of the episodes in the more recent seasons...Again, there's a lot of cool features here; we get commentaries from various people and it was great they still had guys like Al Jean and James L. Brooks come in and talk although they had nothing to do with the season and Mirkin is a lot more bareable as well. We get the TV special to Who Shot Mr. Burns, commercials and deleted scenes, that's all good. I'm satisfied with this boxset and I wish people would stop judging the packaging of this set (Which I admit is annoying.) and take notice of the content.

reviewText: I ordered this season along with seasons seven and eight, and while I had to reorder season eight because it contained two copies of the same disk, the other two were as they should be. So, incidentally, was the new copy of season eight once I reordered it. But I'll discuss the rest of those seasons in separate reviews since I actually came here to discuss the sixth season. This season is so far the only one I've received in the head-shaped packaging. After reading all the negative reviews where sometimes four stars were subtracted based on the package alone, I'll grant that I was nervous about buying them. But I was pleasantly surprised when I received it. The package was easy to open and yet closed securely and didn't fall apart. Nor did the disks, which are in a handy plastic holder with sections for each disk rather like pages in a photo album, fall out. And because I generally stack my DVD's on my entertainment center, the fact that the package doesn't stand welll on its side didn't matter.So now that the packaging is out of the way let's get on to the season itself. Season six features some of my favorite episodes, not the least being Treehouse of Horror V, which features three of my favorite sketches. The Shinning, wherein homer goes crazy from lack of TV and beer and attempts to murder his family with an axe, Time and Punishment, which parodies the butterfly effect and the Ray Bradbury shortstory A Sound of Thunder, and Nightmare Cafeteria, wherein Bart and Lisa make a horrifying discovery at school. There's also Homer the Great, where Homer inadvertently becomes the leader of a secet society of beer-swilling good timers while being kicked out of said society for despoiling the sacred parchment. This episode features the ever so catchy Stonecutters theme song, which is one of my favorite Simpsons songs after Baby on Board. Other notables are Bart of Darkness, Lisa's Rival, and of course we can't forget the cliffhanger beginning to one of the most talked-about Simpsons episodes, part one of Who Shot Mr. Burns? If I'm not mistaken this aired not long before the famous King of the Hill cliffhanger when America spent all that spring and summer wondering who would survive the big Propane explosion at the end of season 2.Aside from the episodes themselves, there is still of course the insightful and often hillarious audio commentary on each episode. And yes folks, these are probably the only features that are likely to matter to a blind Simpsons fan like myself. There are of course also deleted scenes and things like that, making this a set any Simpsons fan should have.

reviewText: The Complete Sixth Season of The Simpsons ran from September 1994 through until May 1995 and is another classic collection of episodes in the much-loved 'Golden Era' of the show. This era, I would guess, is from around 1992 until 1998 where The Simpsons fast became the most important show on television. The sheer wit and social satire in this season is incredible. The writers are perhaps the most talented on this show over any other in America, which is saying a lot for an animated show. Anyway the superlatives keep on coming for The Simpsons and, even though the show has lost a lot of its sheen that made it so groundbreaking in the Nineties, it's still held as a national treasure. Season Six is superb, but I'd say just slightly less superb than Season Five which is probably my favourite.The season opens with the brilliant "Bart Of Darkness," in which Homer installs a pool in the back yard during a heat wave. Bart breaks his leg trying to dive into it, and has to spend the summer indoors. He witnesses Flanders burying something in the back yard and soon believes that he's killed his wife Maude. In "Lisa's Rival," a new student arrives at the school and is better at everything than Lisa. She soon turns to the dark side, however, and enlists Bart's help to destroy her. "Another Simpsons Clip Show" sees Marge inspired by a book to teach her children about romance, which leads to flash backs from all members of the family. In "Itchy And Scratchy Land," the Simpsons take a trip to Itchy And Scratchy Land, billed "the violentest place on earth." Robots soon malfunction and start attacking the family. "Sideshow Bob Roberts" sees Sideshow Bob call into a radio station to secure a release from prison. He runs for mayor and wins as head of the Republican party, then tries to build a freeway overpass over the Simpsons residence, until Lisa reveals how he won the election. "Treehouse Of Horror V" is brilliant and sees the family employed by Burns, Homer attempting to repair a toaster that leads him back into the past, and school children start mysteriously disappearing when the cafeteria turns to an unusual source for food.In "Bart's Girlfriend," Bart begins a romance with Jessica Lovejoy, the mischievous daughter of the local minister. He is blamed for her theft of money from the church collection plate, leaving Lisa to clear his name. "Lisa On Ice" sees Lisa get an F in sport, a subject she doesn't care for, but is devastated about getting such a poor grade. She takes up ice hockey and is surprisingly good, until a match between her team and Bart's raises conflict. In "Homer Badman," Homer is accused of sexual harassment after peeling a sweet off Bart and Lisa's babysitter's bum. The town turns against him, but luckily a tape provided by Groundskeeper Willie proves Homer's innocence. "Grampa Vs. Sexual Inadequacy" sees Homer and his dad sell off a revitalising tonic to the townspeople after Homer and Marge's sex life hits the rocks. "Fear Of Flying" sees Marge enlist the aid of a therapist after the family discover she is afraid of flying. In "Homer The Great," Homer becomes the leader of a Masonic cult known as The Stonecutters. However, the group soon become bored of Homer and ban him from their activities. "And Maggie Makes Three" sees Homer explain, in flashback, the reason why there are no photos of Maggie in the family album. In "Bart's Comet," Bart discovers a comet while on early morning detention with Principle Skinner which is on a collision course with earth.In "Homie The Clown," Krusty opens up a clown college to get more money after advice from his accountant. Homer makes a poor clown but looks remarkably like Krusty, leading to his capture by mobsters who have loaned money to Krusty. "Bart Vs. Australia" sees Bart run up a $900 phone bill to Australia. He is then forced to go to Australia and apologize in public and receive a boot up the butt. Instead he moons the Prime Minister and makes matters a lot worse. In "Homer Vs. Patty And Selma," Homer borrows money from Marge's sisters in a bid to keep his debt problems a secret from her. They soon have him performing humiliating tasks until he find a way to get them to forgive the loan. "A Star Is Burns" sees a film festival come to Springfield. Entries come from Mr. Burns who produces an ego-driven propaganda piece, Hans Moleman getting hit in the groin by a football and a touching piece by Barney. "Lisa's Wedding" sees the Simpson family visit a local fortune teller, who describes Lisa's wedding in the future. She winds up engaged to a British man who can't accept Lisa's family, leaving the present-day Lisa to invest more faith into her family. In "Two Dozen And One Greyhounds," the Simpson dog impregnates another greyhound, leaving the family with a litter of 25 puppies. Mr. Burns steals them for his own evil plans, leaving Bart and Lisa to get them back."The PTA Disbands!" sees the teachers go on strikes when Skinner implements new budget cutbacks on the school. Lisa and even Bart start to miss school, leaving local parents to step in and teach classes. In the end the teachers return after Skinner allows local convicts to share school space. "'Round Springfield" sees Bart get ill from a box of cereal. Lisa visits him in hospital and discovers Bleeding Gums Murphy, her beloved jazz singer. In "The Springfield Connection," Marge gets a job as a police officer after a thrilling confrontation with a street hustler who takes $20 from Homer. Life as a cop isn't much fun, though, and she is forced to arrest Homer. "Lemon Of Troy" sees the children of Springfield come into conflict with the kids of Shelbyville who steal a lemon tree. Homer helps the kids get the tree back after many high-edge thrilling moments. The final episode of the season is the genius "Who Shot Mr. Burns? (Part One)" which is arguably the most notorious episode in The Simpsons history. The fact that this show produced a cliffhanger - for a cartoon! - was genius and groundbreaking, not least of all because the dialogue and story is so complex and perfectly executed.Many people have complained about the packaging of this season because the plastic is shoddy and cheap. I can't really comment because I bought the re-released version that is in the box of the same size and shape as the previous five seasons. They did release the limited edition Homer Head one in the UK, but brought out the one with the normal box a few weeks later - I assume it's the box that Americans can send off for by filling out the order form on the website. The episode guide booklet is also much better than the previous five, much thicker and more detailed. I also like the police theme that dominates the whole box set, obviously based around the Who Shot Mr. Burns? episode. All in all another great addition to any Simpsons fan's collection.
summary: Another Essential From The Simpsons' Golden Era

reviewText: The Simpsons kept up an impressive record of consecutive quality stretching over a dozen seasons or so.  If they have slipped a little lately, well, even MASH and Cheers had their off-seasons.  Season 6 is not the best season (that honour belongs to Season 4), but it could certainly be second-best (and is of the 7 seasons that are currently available).  The "second" set of writers have found their groove and churn out one memorable episode after another.  Ironically, the famous "Who Shot Mr. Burns" cliffhanger is one of the weaker episodes (although still very good - it's just weaker than these other extremely strong episodes).  My highlights are as follows:Lisa's Rival - a Grade 1 student is skipped ahead to Lisa's class, who is younger, smarter, and a better sax player.  Therefore Lisa enlists Bart's help to sabatoge her diorama.Treehouse of Horror V - normally I don't like the Hallowe'en episodes as much as the regular ones, but this one is particularly good.Homer Badman - stupid show title, great show.  Homer is accused of sexually harassing a college student.Homer the Great - the best show of the season.  Homer joins a secret society and is revealed to be the prophesised "Chosen One."  It contains a particularly memorable guest voice by Patrick Stuart and the best song written for the series (with the possible exception of "Baby on Board").And Maggie Makes Three - A flashback episode, wherein Homer quits his job at the Power Plant to become a pin monkey at the bowlarama.A Star is Burns - Barnie wins the first Springfield Film Festival in spite of the fact that Mr. Burns has bribed the jury and over Homer's choice, "Man Getting Hit by Football" (in the groin).Lisa's Wedding - A rare "flash-forward" episode.  Lisa gets engaged to her college sweetheart and they plan their wedding.Two Dozen and One Greyhounds - Santa's Little Helper impregnates another greyhound giving issue to 25 puppies.  Mr. Burns steals them with a Cruela DeVille-like plan to turn them into a tuxedo.As I said above, all of the shows are enjoyable on repeated viewings.  This DVD also has the traditional commentaries on every episode.  While this feature is starting to wear a little thin (they are running out of things to talk about), I was still interested enough to listen to every one of them.  The most important inclusion on this DVD, however, is the 1/2-hour "Springfield's Most Wanted" show - filmed on the set of America's Most Wanted, at the time another of Fox's most popular shows - summarising the suspects in the case of the Mr. Burns's shooting.  I have never heard of this show being shown since its original airing, and it is an invaluable addition to the DVD (even if it isn't as fun as any of the actual shows).
summary: Season 6 - perhaps the 2nd-best season of the show

reviewText: Congratulations to all you packaging-obsessed crybabies out there, you got my attention. Now I'm going to have to waste my time and everyone else's in telling you all to get a life. Most of you forgot to consider the greatness of the original episodes from the tremendous sixth season of the Simpsons. There's a lot of great literature and music that comes with ugly covers. It must be nice not having anything else to organize boycotts about and sign petitions for. But I guess if I were a 34 year-old geek living in my mom's basement, maybe I'd care passionately about packaging too, as my collection of geek memorabilia on my shelf would be all I'd have to impress my geek friends with. Well enough with you losers already, you'll find something else to whine about in a few minutes, such as the next wave of Star Wars action figures.So is it okay if the rest of us care passionately about the Simpsons episodes? Not only was the sixth season the absolute pinnacle of the already lofty Simpsons universe, it was also a super-sized season with 25 episodes. In general, the best episodes of the third and fourth seasons may have been more comedically intricate, and some of the fifth season was more sensitive and hearfelt. But even Matt Groening agrees (in this set's "confession") that the sixth season was the downright funniest, fastest, most Simpsonically relentless season ever. The classic episodes are just too numerous for me to list here, but check out some of the obligatory lists of all-time top ten episodes at various Simpsons fan sites and trivia sites. Everybody's top ten contains at least three or four episodes from this sixth season. Sheesh, I'm even having a hard time picking out the ten best of this season, they're all so excellent.Now if you'll excuse me, I'm going to play these DVDs and disregard the packaging while I soak in classic episode after classic episode, laughing myself hoarse and marveling at the sheer brilliance of the Simpsons production team. I am happy to place this box next to the previous Simpsons collections, and the future collections. [~doomsdayer520~]

reviewText: The animated TV series the Simpsons began in December 1989, and has continued to run for over 17 years, which in itself tells the viewer of its popularity, which has stretched across different generations.  Several critics have even dubbed the Simpsons the best-animated TV series ever.  Its popularity seems to stem from its heavy satirical approach on human conditions within the middle class family of the Simpson that reside in Springfield, Illinois.  Over its 350 some episodes the Simpsons has covered next to all possible contemporary issues from politics to history while also incorporating art and cultural issues.  Besides the satire within the Simpson's, it also brings a wide range of reoccurring characters with extensive individuality, which furthers the intrigue within all the episodes.  However, the core of the story rests around dim-witted father Homer, the able mother Marge, the mischievous son Bart, the gifted daughter Lisa, and eternally thumb sucking baby Maggie.The sixth season stretches between episodes 104 to 128 and in the first episode of season six Bart has to deal with the summer's record heat and neighborly intrusion.  In the other episodes issues such as jealousy, isolation, sexual harassment, failure, success, gravity, and many more interesting themes will capture the viewer's attention through bellyaching humor and wit.  One of the best episodes, Treehouse of Horror V, the Burns requests Homer to look out for their house over the winter.  This episode pays a little homage to the Shinning (1980), one of the best horror films of all time.  Then there is the terrific season finale, Who Shot Mr. Burns?, which deals with greed and prosperity, as the Springfield school finds oil on the school grounds.  Mr. Burns desires the oil, but Principal Skinner does not want to sell.  Every episode provides a unique little visual treat that also offers an interesting perspective on life in America through the amusing Simpsons family.Season 6 picks up where season 5 left off, and leaves the audience with a high motivation to see the impending season 7.  The creator Matt Groening has through returning characters and themes successfully created an animated world with its own mythology, even though it mirrors American culture.  Returning to previous themes elevates the Simpsons appeal, as it helps create something to which the audience can relate.  It also helps the viewers to see some of the messages in a different perspective, which suggests that the Simpsons is something much more than just a mere spoof.  Lastly, many viewers of the Simpsons should be excited to know that this series has a contract that runs through the 2007-2008 season.What's great with the Simpsons is that one could watch these episodes any time of the day at any location.  Thus, in today's society where several vehicles are equipped with DVD players and small screen or portable DVD players, they offer a great opportunity to catch one of these old episodes again.  If one is interrupted, it is easy to get back into the show.  Another great thing with the Simpsons is that it has an excellent replay value, as the jokes remain amusing even after several viewings.  Lastly, the Simpsons offers a little for everyone in the family, which also makes it a great family experience.
summary: An Exceptionally Amusing Perspective of the American Culture...

reviewText: The greatest TV show ever made came into it's own in season 5, but season 6 contains some of my all-time favorite episodes, including Homer the Great, Bart of Darkness, Sideshow Bob Roberts, Lemon of Troy and Bart Vs. Australia. And of course, the Dallas-inspired episode 2-parter Who Shot Mr. Burns, which will be concluded in the season 7 box set. Now in its 16th season and still going strong, The Simpsons is up there with Seinfeld as one of the best, the truly great TV shows that come along once, maybe twice in a lifetime. Every week audiences across the world tune in to the crazy little cartoon for laughs. Homer Simpson, of course, is the epitome of the lazy American, Bart and Lisa, the parallel kids and Marge the `normal' wife. And of course, Maggie and Santa's little helper. My favorite characters have always been Homer and Mr. Burns. Not that I really identify with them, rather that they are the exact opposites of the kind of person I am, and that, in itself, is what makes a personality so comedicly rich. Matt Groening has tapped into something really special. Whether diabolically evil or extraordinarily lazy, every nutball in Springfield is well-written and endearing. And then of course, there's Danny Elfman's fantastic theme music. Gifted voice actors like Hank Azaria and Dan Castellenta add so much to Simpsons, showcasing their enthusiasm and undeniable talent. reviewText: Thank you, Don't Need No Stinkin' Badge. I do actually look for replies to my reviews, and yours was very helpful. Yes, it won't fit on my rack with the other seasons of Simpsons DVDs. But this is not my biggest complaint with the set. Starting with season five, and again in season six, the DVD makers have, for some reason, decided to omit subtitles. That would be irritating enough were I hearing impaired. But when I watch a DVD with the audio commentary I like to have the subtitles on so I can still follow along with what is happening in the episode. Granted, I've seen all of these episodes over and over, but I don't have the dialog committed to memory. That is my big complaint with both season five and season six.Getting back to the box. Realizing they screwed up, they include with the set a piece of paper stating, "For all those that fear change...for all those anal-retentive nerds who like their DVD boxes to line up perfectly on the shelf...for all those who dislike storing their digital media inside a hollowed-out human head, have we got a deal for you." I'm sure the team that put that together thought they were being extremely clever. Anyway, the note includes a phone number (800-223-2369) where you call and listen to some bonehead doing a really bad Homer impression mock you some more before directing you to a website ([...]) where you have to fill in a form and are told how to order the replacement box. The new box is apparently free, but you still have to pay the $2.95 shipping and handling ($4.95 for Canada). To keep people from ordering free boxes willy-nilly, you have to include either your original sales receipt, the 800# insert, or the proof of purchase from the back of the booklet (which means you can theoretically order three of them if you're so inclined).Lack of subtitles and poor packaging aside, season six is probably one of my all-time favorite seasons. It has some truly inspired episodes: Itchy & Scratchy Land where the robots run amuck; Treehouse of Horror V, probably the best of the Halloween episodes with the spoof of The Shining, the time-traveling toaster, and the cannibalistic cafeteria; Homer Badman with the pop-rocks & coke hand grenade and Dennis Franz; Homer the Great and the Stone-Cutter song; Two Dozen and One Greyhounds with the "See My Vest" song; and Lemon of Troy with the Shelbyville doppelgangers of Bart, Milhouse, and the gang. Any huge Simpsons fan will get this regardless of what I say. If you're not a huge Simpsons fan, I would highly recommend this as one season definitely worth buying.I'm only giving this three stars, though. That is a direct result of the subtitles and packaging. If you've ever ripped a DVD you know that subtitles take up practically no space whatsoever. I can't imaging why they would have decided to stop putting episode subtitles on these season sets. And I do hope that the lame-brain who decided to change the packaging gets the boot. reviewText: Finally!  A proper box for this excellent Simpsons season!  It fits so snugly and looks so nice on the shelf with the others.  Whoever thought of those head cases is a head case!  Anyway, as for the season--it is great!  The Simpsons kept improving each season until reaching its peak (in my opinion) in season 7.  Then it started its rapid downhill plunge after season 8.Season 6 is The Simpsons in its prime.  It includes many of their best episodes, some of which are on my personal top 20 list (i.e. Bart's Comet, Lemons of Troy, Lisa's Wedding, Round Springfield, and Who Shot Mr. Burns? Part 1). The shows include: Bart of Darkness, Lisa's Rival, Another Simpsons Clip Show, Treehouse of Horror V (with parodies of the Shining and Mr. Peabody and Sherman), Bart's Girlfriend, Lisa on Ice (the ice hockey episode), Grampa vs. Sexual Inadequacy, Fear of Flying, Homie the Clown, Bart vs. Australia, Homer vs. Patty and Selma, A Star is Burns, Two Dozen and One Greyhounds, The PTA Disbands, The Springfield Connection (Marge becomes a cop). All the episodes are excellent (Springfield Connection is probably the weakest of the group), but to save space, the following are synopses of a few of my favorites of the 25 episodes in season 6:Itchy & Scratchy Land: Lisa and Bart nag Homer into agreeing to a family vacation to "the violentest place of earth" with such attractions as "Searing Gas Pain Land" and "Unnecessary Surgery Land." The documentary on Roger Meyers Sr. is hilarious: he was criticized in 1938 for his cartoon "Nazi Supermen are our Superiors."Sideshow Bob Roberts: This show includes a hilariously accurate parody of Rush Limbaugh, Birch Barlow. The Conservative talk show host starts an uproar to get Sideshow Bob out of prison and the vote-conscious Mayor Quimby complies only to face Bob in his reelection campaign. The campaign commercials are great!Bart's Girlfriend:  Bart falls for Rev. Lovejoy's daughter, Jessica, who is not what she seems.Lisa On Ice:  Lisa finally finds a sports position she is good at--hockey goalie.  Unfortunately, Bart plays for a rival team.Homer Badman: Homer is accused of sexual harassment by the babysitter. The media circus that follows is brilliant in its real world accuracy.Homer the Great: Homer wants all the quirks enjoyed by members of the sacred fraternity The Stonecutters. He must honor the sacred parchment or his stomach will become bloated and his head plucked of all but three hairs...wait a minute?!?And Maggie Makes Three: A touching look at the sacrifice Homer makes to afford the new arrival. He quits his dream job at the bowling alley to crawl [literally] back to Mr. Burns where he receives the customary de-motivational plague...er, plaque.Bart's Comet: Bart discovers a comet and it's headed right at Springfield! The townspeople then engage in the classic debate of who should be saved in the limited bomb shelter space. A congressional bill to evacuate Springfield is voted down after a rider is attached to support the perverted arts.Lisa's Wedding: This episode was voted #1 by TV Guide. It is one of my favorites, too. Lisa has her fortune read and learns about a love she'll meet in college (Hugh Grant parody, Hugh Parkfield). We then get a glimpse of the Simpsons family in the future. Lisa shows her devotion to her crude, yet well-meaning, father.Round Springfield: Another touching episode where Lisa loses her friend Bleeding Gums Murphy and vows to keep jazzman's memory alive.Lemons of Troy: Kids from the rival town Shelbyville steal the Springfield lemon tree (the sweetest fruit known during the time of their forefathers) and Bart and the gang are intent on getting it back. From this episode, we learn that the two towns were created due to a split that developed among a group of pioneers led by Jebediah Springfield and Shelbyville Manhattan over the legality of marrying cousins.Who Shot Mr. Burns (Part One): In the spirit of J.R., Mr. Burns is shot after he steals oil from a well built on the Springfield Elementary School grounds and unleashes a device that blocks the sun's rays over the town. For poetic justice's sake (or maybe, there's more to it than that), Mr. Burns falls on top of the town sundial and the hunt is on for the shooter. Sounds like a good story for a sequel....

Many hilarious events occur here, such as Homer getting labeled a pervert ("Homer Badman") and later getting labeled the "chosen one" by the Stonecutters cult ("Homer the Great"). Other episodes, including classics "Lemon of Troy" and the spoof of Jurassic Park "Itchy & Scratchy Land", are here as well, and the "Treehouse of Horror" episode this season is one of the best you'll ever see.  The guest voice cast this season is possibly the best the series had to offer at this point, including Streep, Patrick Stewart, Winona Ryder, Mel Brooks, Susan Sarandon, and Jon Lovitz playing film critic Jay Sherman (a crossover episode trying to boost ratings of the ill-fated animated series the Critic).  All in all, season six of the Simpsons is pure animated brilliance and lunacy, but the DVD packaging is possibly the flimsiest you'll ever come across, so if you purchase this set, be careful opening it.

reviewText: Season 6 is not where the Simpsons "jumped the shark" - but the shark clearly entered the pool two seasons ago - and this season, the Fonz is putting fuel in his bike.  This is evidenced by the first five episodes of the season, all of them second-rate.  It isn't until the Halloween episode that some good starts to shine through.  This season's good to bad ratio is 16 good, 9 bad.  Still pretty good odds.  And, the good episodes in this season are also some of the best of the series as a whole, including my Top Five favorite, "HOMER BAD MAN" which features Homer being prosecuted for "sexual harassment" because he peeled a gummi "Venus De Milo" off the rear of his children's babysitter.  Other season highlights include what was probably the ONLY good trip outside of Springfield the family took (to Australia), a collision with a killer comet (in which Congress cannot act to save the town because the "Save Springfield/Perverted Arts" bill fails to pass!), Mr. Burns' great musical number ("See My Vest"), a memorable teacher's strike, and the Stone Cutters lodge (where we finally learn the secret to Steve Guttenberg's stardom)!But for all its good, the dark cloud that signals the imminent arrival of Season 8 is looming strongly in this set.  One can see the many measures being taken to hold viewers attention - first, a clip-show within only the first three episodes, as if to remind the viewers what a great show the Simpsons has been.  Second, the rising number of celebrity voiceovers, with no less than 7 "guest stars."  And then, the famous cliffhanger episode - a final bid to make viewers return for another season - granted, "WHO SHOT MR. BURNS" is classic Simpsons - but the signal is all too clear!And, it would seem that history is repeating itself this year as well - the distributors clearly see that the dreaded chasm that is Season 8 is close at hand - this is where my theory about the box cover comes in.  When quality episodes can no longer be assured, the distributors have struck upon an idea: "Why not make the next couple of seasons look like the characters - that way, the collector types will HAVE to buy Season 8, 9, 10 . . . to ensure they get the entire collection for their libraries!"  Clever, guys - but it's not going to fool me!  I'll go Season 7, and I might even be induced to get Season 8, if only for the Halloween and X-Files episodes - but that's as far as THIS collector goes!Meanwhile - get Season 6, it's still worth the money!*Final note - I'm not hugely fond of changing the look of a DVD package within a set - but I kinda like the hollow head thing anyway!  It seems flimsy, but once you open it and look inside, I think they kinda pull it off ok!  Plus - they even include a number you can call to exchange yours for a set more like the first five seasons! How generous of them!!
summary: Two seasons away from THE GREAT DECLINE, and My Theory on the New Box Covers . . .
